: : Great insights Peter. Now I have thought it over some more I would
: have
: : to agree with you and Jim. Would love to find out if they did indeed
: use
: : an irregular hammer and anvil in the old days, I wonder if anyone else
: : could give us some more thoughts on this?
: :
: : I can highly recommend Graham Gemmell's book: Tosogu, treasure of the
: : samurai. It is infact a catalog of an exhibition/sale held in London
: in
: : '91 at a big name Gallery.  Very beautiful book with great
: illustrations
: : and very interesting thoughts on the pieces that were on show. Also it
: : just occured to me that none of these pieces are papered, at least
: there
: : is no mention of any papers whatsoever anywhere in the catalog.
: :
: : Talking about surface finishes, I was wondering about the 'cat
: scratch'
: : finish we often see on the back of kozuka and kogai. What purpose does
: : this serve and when did this practice begin? Is it at all related to
: : 'cat scratch habaki' that have that texture not only for the beauty of
: : it, but also because it secures the sword in the saya a tiny bit more?
: : Also we often see this motif in combination with a polished shakudo or
: : other ground, sometimes in the form of two triangles, sometimes simply
: : two rectangles next to each other. Is there any reason for this, a
: : kantei point perhaps?
: :
: : - Matt

: :
: : Matt,
: : You have engendered an interesting discussion and elicited Jim's
: usually
: : worthwhile insights. Thanks
: : In response to your comments, I took a look again and some of my
: : katchushi
: : guards last night (they used to be so common and cheap that I couldn't
: : avoid becoming a 'collector'). I have always loved the finish of these
: : tsuba which looks old and natural but which is also obviously the
: : creation
: : of human intention. I am not familiar with Gemmell's book, but - like
: : Jim -
: : I am sceptical about the use of a pointed hammer to created tsuba
: : surfaces.
: : I can believe that a kinko might make and use a hammer with a network
: of
: : very fine points. As I think about it, use of irregular hammer and
: anvil
: : surfaces during the forging of the initial plate might be a means of
: : setting up the internal irregularities we call bones etc.
: : I agree with Jim, too, that whatever means was used to created a
: surface
: : finish, it probably involved a chisel or punch rather than direct
: : pounding
: : with a hammer.
: : In that regard, let me recall a conversation with Hagawa-san, the
: Sendai
: : kinko I have mentioned to the list before. He makes frequent use of
: : "ishime" which is a smooth but 'irregular' surface of small dots that
: : looks
: : like a stone (ishi means stone). He told me that ishime is as hard to
: do
: : as
: : nanako. It is done with specially crested punches ('tagane') that are
: : struck with a hammer - one dot at a time. Hagawa-san said that once
: : started, an entire surface had to be done in one setting to assure a
: : uniform texture. If the work was interrupted, the piece will be
: ruined.
: : Thus, before he starts an ishime surface, he tells his wife and family
: : that
: : they should not interrupt him til the tapping stopped. Maybe the point
: : here
: : is that even if special tools are used, it is still the craftsman's
: : skill
: : and intensity that matters.
: :
: : Peter Bleed
